docs.snippet: LEAD: BEGINNING this month and continuing through the next year, voters in more than a dozen Latin American countries will be going to the polls to render judgment on a decade of hardship. Though the 1980's have been marked by the disappearance of...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: BEGINNING this month and continuing through the next year, voters in more than a dozen Latin American countries will be going to the polls to render judgment on a decade of hardship. Though the 1980's have been marked by the disappearance of military dictatorship and the emergence of democratic civilian rule in one country after another, that shift, like the coming cycle of presidential elections, has occurred against a backdrop of a continentwide economic crisis that has left the people disenchanted and newly implanted institutions vulnerable.

docs.snippet: LEAD: There were times last year when Michael Chang was reduced to a footnote in the Andre Agassi story. Agassi had flair - a punk rock hairdo and equally colorful personality -plus a game that vaulted him to six tournament titles and No. 3 in the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: There were times last year when Michael Chang was reduced to a footnote in the Andre Agassi story. Agassi had flair - a punk rock hairdo and equally colorful personality -plus a game that vaulted him to six tournament titles and No. 3 in the world. Chang preferred a brush cut and an impassive expression on the court, masking his emotions.

headline.main: Chang on Rise but He's Still Not in Agassi's Act

docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States plays plenty unfair in foreign trade but you'd never know it from the sanctimonious attack that Washington is about to launch against the ''unfair'' trade restrictions of other countries. It's a dangerous strategy that risks...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The United States plays plenty unfair in foreign trade but you'd never know it from the sanctimonious attack that Washington is about to launch against the ''unfair'' trade restrictions of other countries. It's a dangerous strategy that risks more restrictions, not fewer - and a global recession. The best course against such foreign offenses is more parry, less thrust.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As the political crisis in Panama deepens, Latin American countries are finding themselves torn between their disgust at the vote fraud apparently committed in the presidential election and their traditional desire not to become too closely aligned with the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TENNIS Wilander Struggles to Gain: Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden had to struggle against Javier Frana of Argentina before prevailing, 6-7, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in his opening-round match at the Italian Open in Rome. Jimmy Connors, seeded fifth, breezed past Cedric Pioline of France, 6-4, 6-2, in the first round.

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: On the eve of Washington's crackdown on so-called ''unfair'' trade restrictions by other countries, an international panel has ruled that one of America's most outrageous restrictions is unfair, too: the quota on sugar imports. The timing is...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: On the eve of Washington's crackdown on so-called ''unfair'' trade restrictions by other countries, an international panel has ruled that one of America's most outrageous restrictions is unfair, too: the quota on sugar imports. The timing is coincidental, but the message is clear. Unfair trade, like fair trade, works both ways.

headline.main: America's Trade Curbs Are Unfair, Too
